Line 6: Line 6:
==Background==
==Background==
â
In 2006, Ollanta Humala [[Peruvian general election, 2006|lost]] a run-off to [[Alan Garcia]]. One reason for his loss was a perception that he too close to Venezuelan President [[Hugo Chavez]] and the latter's [[Bolivarian revolution]] based on the principles of [[21st century socialism]] and that he was a part of the "[[pink tide]]" in Latin America. However, five years later he [[Peruvian general election, 2011|beat]] [[Keiko Fujimori]] in a run-off, in part because he distanced himself from Chavez and aligned with the ideas of [[Lula da Silva]] in Brazil, who also experienced similar rapid growth as the [[economy of Peru]]. Prior to his official inauguration Humala undertook a tour of American states including Bolivia, Colombia and the United States. (his tour of Venezuela was postponed til 15 July, 2011 due to Chavez's health concerns as he underwent surgery in Cuba<ref>http://english.eluniversal.com/2011/07/14/ollanta-humala-to-visit-chavez-in-caracas.shtml
+
In 2006, Ollanta Humala [[Peruvian general election, 2006|lost]] a run-off to [[Alan Garcia]]. One reason for his loss was a perception that he too close to Venezuelan President [[Hugo Chavez]] and the latter's [[Bolivarian revolution]] based on the principles of [[21st century socialism]] and that he was a part of the "[[pink tide]]" in Latin America. However, five years later he [[Peruvian general election, 2011|beat]] [[Keiko Fujimori]] in a run-off, in part because he distanced himself from Chavez and aligned with the ideas of [[Lula da Silva]] in Brazil, who also experienced similar rapid growth as the [[economy of Peru]]. Prior to his official inauguration Humala undertook a tour of American states including Bolivia, Colombia and the United States. (his tour of Venezuela was postponed til 15 July, 2011 due to Chavez's health concerns as he underwent surgery in Cuba<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2011/07/14/ollanta-humala-to-visit-chavez-in-caracas.shtml |title=Ollanta Humala to visit ChÃ¡vez in Caracas - Daily News |publisher=El Universal |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>). Upon resumption of the Venezuela leg of his tour the business community in Peru were concerned that Humala may drift back towards to Chavez's policies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2011/07/15/humala-chavez-and-chavismo/ |title=Humala, ChÃ¡vez and Chavismo | beyondbrics | News and views on emerging markets from the Financial Times â FT.com |publisher=Blogs.ft.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
â
</ref>). Upon resumption of the Venezuela leg of his tour the business community in Peru were concerned that Humala may drift back towards to Chavez's policies.<ref>http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2011/07/15/humala-chavez-and-chavismo/
  â
</ref>
 
His inauguration on 28 July was due to be attended by regional leaders.
His inauguration on 28 July was due to be attended by regional leaders.
Line 13: Line 13:
Following a meeting in 2006 with Bolivian President [[Evo Morales]] in [[Copacabana, Bolivia]] on the Bolivian border with Peru, in which Humala stated that he stood in "solidarity with the historical and legitimate demand of the Bolivian Republic,"<ref>[http://www.larepublica.com.pe/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=110134&Itemid=565&fecha_edicion=2006-05-09&fecha_edicion=2006-05-09 "Humala solidario con demanda boliviana de salida al mar"]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} May 8, 2006 ''La Republica'' {{es icon}}</ref> after his electoral victory in 2011 he went back to Bolivia and made calls for the resurrection of the [[PeruâBolivian Confederation]].
Following a meeting in 2006 with Bolivian President [[Evo Morales]] in [[Copacabana, Bolivia]] on the Bolivian border with Peru, in which Humala stated that he stood in "solidarity with the historical and legitimate demand of the Bolivian Republic,"<ref>[http://www.larepublica.com.pe/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=110134&Itemid=565&fecha_edicion=2006-05-09&fecha_edicion=2006-05-09 "Humala solidario con demanda boliviana de salida al mar"]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} May 8, 2006 ''La Republica'' {{es icon}}</ref> after his electoral victory in 2011 he went back to Bolivia and made calls for the resurrection of the [[PeruâBolivian Confederation]].
â
During a visit to Washington D.C. Humala also met [[Organization of American States]]' Secretary-General [[Jose Miguel Insulza]] in which he said Peru intends to work towards greater [[Latin American integration|regional integration]].<ref>http://www.livinginperu.com/news/15491</ref> During the same tour he also met with US [[Secretary of State]] [[Hilary Clinton]] on Washington D.C. During the meeting US President [[Barack Obama]] made a surprise appearance to meet Humala, a visit that was appreciated by the latter. Obama spoke of the importance of "sound market-based economic policies with efforts to increase economic and social inclusion."<ref>http://www.andina.com.pe/ingles/Noticia.aspx?id=ldP68UyW5+Q=</ref>
+
During a visit to Washington D.C. Humala also met [[Organization of American States]]' Secretary-General [[Jose Miguel Insulza]] in which he said Peru intends to work towards greater [[Latin American integration|regional integration]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livinginperu.com/news/15491 |title=News Â» Ollanta Humala reaffirms his commitment to Peruvian-Bolivian solidarity |publisher=Living in Peru |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref> During the same tour he also met with US [[Secretary of State]] [[Hilary Clinton]] on Washington D.C. During the meeting US President [[Barack Obama]] made a surprise appearance to meet Humala, a visit that was appreciated by the latter. Obama spoke of the importance of "sound market-based economic policies with efforts to increase economic and social inclusion."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/ingles/Noticia.aspx?id=ldP68UyW5+Q= |title=Humala, Obama agree Peru, US should be 'equal partners' | ANDINA - Peru News Agency |publisher=ANDINA |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
â
During his postponed trip to Venezuela, Humala was personally welcomes by Chavez at [[Miraflores Palace]]. He reiterated calls for regional integreation saying "As 200 years ago, when we fought colonialism, today we have common enemies like poverty, inequalities, drug trafficking and so many threats against our countries. I have come as a friend and a brother; and this brotherhood leads us to a similar futur." He also wished Chavez a recovery from his cancer treatment: "We are giving you support, please count on our forces and the prayers of the Peruvian people, who want your recovery because you have a mission to accomplish."<ref>http://www.escambray.cu/Eng/world/humala110715943</ref>
+
During his postponed trip to Venezuela, Humala was personally welcomes by Chavez at [[Miraflores Palace]]. He reiterated calls for regional integreation saying "As 200 years ago, when we fought colonialism, today we have common enemies like poverty, inequalities, drug trafficking and so many threats against our countries. I have come as a friend and a brother; and this brotherhood leads us to a similar futur." He also wished Chavez a recovery from his cancer treatment: "We are giving you support, please count on our forces and the prayers of the Peruvian people, who want your recovery because you have a mission to accomplish."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.escambray.cu/Eng/world/humala110715943 |title=Ollanta Humala Welcomed by Chavez in Venezuela â Escambray |publisher=Escambray.cu |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
